text_en: But I was wondering why in the end this protagonist has to die in such a cruel way for justice to be done. I mean, why is it always the sacrifice for... I mean, why do we have to die, basically. But something very beautiful happens, and you already know it because you have gone to the Renoir cinemas to see the film. Something very nice happens with which she.... She kind of, once she dies, she speaks from the phone, from the other side, as if from the beyond. It's like some messages that she has left programmed... we read them and they are read by the characters who are still alive once she is dead, but it is as if there was a beyond, a space, again, that is not represented, where she is and maybe she is not alone, because when she appears, the police find the place where she has died and has been burned, because the guys who kill her burn the body, there is the necklace of her friend, they had a necklace, the typical teenage heart in which half had a name, half had another, and there is the name of her friend. In other words, there is a space there that, in this case, is death.
